By Jon Herskovitz and Heide Brandes
Oklahoma's Republican Governor Mary Fallin vetoed a bill calling for prison terms of up the three years for doctors who performed abortions
column2: saying the legislation would not withstand a criminal constitutional legal challenge
column3: her office said on Friday.The bill
column4: which was approved a day earlier in the Republican-dominated legislature
column5: would have made performing an abortion a felony. It also called for revoking the license of any doctor who conducted one.The bill allowed an exemption for an abortion necessary to save the life of the mother.""The bill is so ambiguous and so vague that doctors cannot be certain what medical circumstances would be considered 'necessary to preserve the life of the mother
column6: '"" Fallin said
column7: in a statement from her office
column8: where she was described as ""the most pro-life governor in the nation.""Abortion rights groups had promised a bruising legal battle if the bill were signed into law
column9: which would have resulted in an expensive legal battle.

column1: Cash-strapped Oklahoma is battling a $1.3 billion budget hole that has caused it to cut education funding and other state programs.Had the bill been approved
column2: the state would have been the first to use its codes of professional conduct to implement a measure that would effectively serve as an abortion ban
column3: according to the Guttmacher Institute
column4: which backs abortion rights but whose data is used by both sides of the debate.

column1: Other states that have tried to impose outright abortion bans after the Supreme Court's landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade decision have seen their laws struck down by courts
column2: it said.Supporters have said the bill could withstand a legal challenge because the state was within its rights to set licensing requirement for doctors.Legal experts have said the U.S. Supreme Court has ruled that abortion is legal in the United States and Oklahoma must abide by the court's decision.

column1: Since Fallin took office in 2011
column2: Oklahoma has been one of the leaders in adding restrictions to abortions.""Governor Fallin did the right thing today in vetoing this utterly unconstitutional and dangerous bill
column3: said Nancy Northup
column4: president and chief executive officer of the Center for Reproductive Rights
column5: an abortion rights group.  (Reporting by Jon Herskovitz in Austin
column6: Texas and Heide Brandes in Oklahoma City; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Fallin'

column1: WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama will meet with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Washington next month to discuss security and other issues and the Indian leader will be granted the rare honor of addressing both houses of Congress.The White House said Obama and Modi will discuss economic growth
column2: climate change
column3: clean energy
column4: and security and defense cooperation during their June 7 meeting. It will be Modi's fourth trip to the United States since he became prime minister in 2014.   ""The visit will highlight the deepening of the U.S.-India relationship in key areas
column5: the White House said in a statement on Friday. The two countries' partnership is seen as critical in Washington
column6: which is seeking to counterbalance China's increasing power. Modi will address a joint meeting of the U.S. Congress
column7: an opportunity extended to few foreign leaders
column8: the day after the White House meeting
column9: U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan said in a tweet.

column1: The invitation is a sharp turnaround for Modi
column2: who was once barred from the United States over massacres of Muslims. Last  year there were only two joint addresses to Congress - by Pope Francis and by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe
column3: another important U.S. ally in Asia.In 2005

column9: and India's Supreme Court in 2010 ruled there was no case.

By Michael Holden and Susan Heavey
LONDON/WASHINGTON - Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said on Friday that British Prime Minister David Cameron had asked him to visit
column2: but a UK spokesman said no invitation had been extended.The apparent crossed signals were the latest sign of tension between the presumptive Republican Party nominee and the leader of a major U.S. ally
column3: who has criticized Trump's call for a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States.Trump
column4: in a morning interview with MSNBC
column5: said Cameron extended the invitation to visit 10 Downing Street two days ago and that he ""might do it."" He gave no other details.A spokesman for Cameron's office said it was a longstanding practice for the prime minister to meet with the Republican and Democrat presidential nominees if they visited Britain. ""Given the parties have yet to choose their nominees
column6: there are no confirmed dates for this
column7: the spokesman said.

column1: However
column2: a Downing Street source said a formal invite would not be sent out to presidential candidates.       Trump's comments followed a transatlantic exchange between the two men over Cameron's criticism. In December
column3: Cameron called Trump ""divisive
column4: stupid and wrong"" and suggested Trump would unite Britain against him if he visited the United Kingdom.

column1: After Trump clinched his party's nomination this month
column2: Cameron acknowledged the achievement but said he stood by his earlier comments and would not apologize. Trump fired back this week
column3: saying on Monday that he was likely not to have a good relationship with Cameron.    But the next day he said he expected to have ""a good relationship"" and on Friday Trump said Cameron had invited him to London.

column1: I will do just fine with David Cameron. I think he's a nice guy. I will do just fine

column4: who was elected mayor of London this month and is the first Muslim to hold the post. Khan said last week that Trump's ""ignorant view of Islam could make both our countries less safe."" column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-defense-lgbt-idUSKCN0YA2II	Lawmakers vote down LGBT rights measure	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Shouts of ""Shame
column2: shame
column3: shame
column4: erupted in the U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday as Republican lawmakers narrowly defeated legislation to protect the civil rights of lesbian
column5: gay
column6: bisexual and transgender employees of government contractors.The measure
column7: an amendment to a veterans and military construction spending bill introduced by New York Democrat Sean Maloney
column8: initially had enough ""yes"" votes to pass
column9: according to the count in the House chamber.But House Republican leaders extended the time allowed for the vote as they urged enough party members to change their positions to defeat it by a vote of 213 to 212.All 183 Democrats who voted backed the amendment
column10: joined by 29 Republicans. All 213 ""no"" votes were from Republicans. Eight House members - three Republicans and five Democrats - did not vote. Lawmakers are allowed to change their vote in the few minutes between voting and the result being declared.    LGBT rights have been a hot-button issue during the 2016 election season. National politics have featured debate over whether making cakes for same-sex couples violates bakers' religious freedom or whether the government should decide which public bathrooms are used by transgender people.

column1: Democrats chanted ""Shame
column2: shame
column3: shame
column4: at Republicans. ""House Republicans are so committed to discriminating against LGBT Americans
column5: that they broke regular order to force their members to reverse their votes and support Republicans' bigotry
column6: Nancy Pelosi
column7: the House Democratic leader
column8: said in a statement.Republicans who backed the provision said it was necessary to protect the religious rights of military contractors and not intended to be discriminatory.

column1: Thursday's emotionally-charged vote came hours after the House late on Wednesday passed a $602 billion defense authorization bill that included ""religious freedom"" language that critics said would allow contractors to discriminate against LGBT individuals.The House Rules committee had angered Democrats by voting along party lines late on Tuesday not to allow a vote on an amendment to the National Defense Authorization Act that would have eliminated that language.The House also backed by 265-159 a separate Democratic amendment to the spending bill that limits the display of the Confederate battle flag on flagpoles at federal veterans' cemeteries.
The measure angered some conservative Republicans from southern states
column2: who argue that the flag is a symbol of their heritage.Some lawmakers have been seeking to limit displays of the Confederate banner since a racially motivated murder of nine black parishioners at a church in Charleston
column3: S.C.  last year. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Tom Brown and Alistair Bell)"	[]	[]

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-arizona-education-idUSKCN0YB08C	Arizona governor declares victory in $3.5-billion education vote	"
By David Schwartz
| PHOENIX
PHOENIX Arizona voters have narrowly approved a plan to pump $3.5 billion into education coffers over the next decade and put an end to a long-running legal battle
column2: Republican Governor Doug Ducey said late on Thursday.The measure
column3: approved by state lawmakers and Ducey last year
column4: provides for Arizona to tap its land trust fund and provide an additional $300 for each student
column5: from kindergarten through 12th grade
column6: in public and charter schools.Arizona has historically ranked near the bottom of states in funding education.The latest unofficial results from Tuesday's special election showed the measure garnering 50.82 percent of votes cast throughout the southwestern U.S. state
column7: and while some 30
column9: Ducey declared victory.""This is a huge victory for public education in Arizona
column10: Ducey said in a statement. ""After years of lawsuits and fighting
column11: we are moving forward and funding our teachers
column12: students and schools - instead of lawyers.""

column1: Voter approval was required because the measure involved a change to the state's constitution.The narrow margin of the result proved that a sizeable number of voters disliked the plan
column2: said Morgan Abraham
column3: chairman of the ""No"" campaign.

column1: This tells me that voters want to fund education the right way
column2: not through the trust fund
column3: but with general funds
column4: Abraham said
column5: adding that he was disappointed by the outcome of the vote.Much of the controversy during the campaign centered on the funding
column6: with critics saying Arizona was jeopardizing its future by taking too much money from its land trust fund.About 60 percent of the new money will come from the trust fund
column7: and the rest from the state's general fund.

column1: The governor's office brokered the deal in a bid to end a 2010 lawsuit by a group of school districts and organizations that charged Arizona with failing to fund mandated inflation adjustments to schools during a recent recession.     The state's highest court already had ruled in favor of the plaintiffs and the court case was being appealed by the state at the time of the deal. column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-vietnam-obama-idUSKCN0YB00N	Obama grapples with Vietnam arms ban
column2: human rights on eve of trip	"

column1: By Matt Spetalnick and David Brunnstrom
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama is still grappling with a historic decision on whether to lift the U.S. arms embargo on Vietnam just days before he travels there
column2: the White House said on Thursday
column3: signaling that human rights concerns could be a sticking point.Support has grown within the U.S. administration and on Capitol Hill to fully remove or at least further ease the ban on weapons sales
column4: bolstering ties between former wartime enemies Washington and Hanoi to counter a rising China. But Obama also faces stiff opposition in some quarters.Ending the embargo - something Vietnam has long sought - would sweep away one of the last major vestiges of the Vietnam War era as Obama makes his first trip there beginning on Monday.It would also anger Beijing
column5: which condemned Obama's partial lifting of the ban in 2014 as interference in the region.The U.S. deliberations come amid increased  tensions in the disputed South China Sea. Beijing demanded an end to U.S. surveillance in the area on Thursday after two of its fighter jets carried out what the Pentagon said was an ""unsafe"" intercept of a U.S. military reconnaissance aircraft.Ben Rhodes
column6: Obama's deputy national security adviser
column7: said the administration has not yet finalized a decision on lifting the three-decade-old embargo but dodged a question on when - or even whether - an announcement might be made soon.

column1: It will be a subject of discussion with the Vietnamese
column2: he told reporters in a preview of Obama's trip
column3: saying the president would explain his thinking to the country's communist leadership. ""It's something that we obviously have been looking at ... in the context of our broader relationship.""White House officials made clear that the final decision would be linked in part to Vietnam's human rights situation.Concerns remain
column4: especially among rights advocates and some U.S. lawmakers
column5: over the government's heavy-handedness toward political opponents and treatment of workers. There is also worry that Washington will lose some leverage if it gives up the arms embargo without securing concessions for reforms.

column1: 'UPGRADE' IN RELATIONSHIP
Still
column2: some of Obama's aides are mindful that a failure to satisfy Vietnam's calls for rescinding the ban could inject a sour note into a visit meant to open a new chapter in security and economic relations. Some Vietnamese officials are suspicious that the United States seeks to undermine their one-party rule.""What we want to demonstrate with this visit is a significant upgrade in the relationship between the United States and Vietnam as partners on many issues even as we have significant areas of difference
column3: Rhodes said.

column1: Obama
column2: who will make stops in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City

column5: as well as its new prime minister
column6: Nguyen Xuan Phuc
column7: and Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong. He will also meet dissidents and will deliver a speech to the Vietnamese people
column8: Rhodes saidU.S. officials say that no matter the decision on the weapons ban they expect Obama's visit to yield tangible steps to boost military cooperation. Washington is looking for increased port visits by U.S. warships
column9: possibly including access to the strategic port at Cam Ranh Bay
column11: according to a person close to U.S. thinking on the subject.(Story refiles to add dropped letter to ""rights"" in lead.) (Writing by Matt Spetalnick; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"	['Hill'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-climatechange-un-idUSKCN0YA2SO	Incoming U.N. climate chief seeks swift action: at odds with Trump	"
By Alister Doyle
| OSLO

OSLO The United Nations's incoming climate chief said on Thursday she will push for rapid action under a U.N. accord to slow global warming and expressed hopes that U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump will drop calls for a renegotiation if elected.Mexico's Patricia Espinosa
column2: a former foreign minister appointed on Wednesday to head the Bonn-based U.N. Climate Change Secretariat from July
column3: urged all governments swiftly to ratify the 195-nation accord hammered out in Paris in December.She told Reuters that ""it's not impossible"" that the agreement
column4: seeking to transform the global economy away from fossil fuels this century
column5: could enter into force as early as this year
column6: giving it strength in international law.Espinosa is at odds with Trump
column7: who is skeptical that man-made emissions cause climate change. He told Reuters on Tuesday that he was ""not a big fan"" of the Paris accord and that ""at a minimum I will be renegotiating those agreements"".Asked about Trump's threat
column8: Espinosa said the Paris deal was a hard-won compromise by more than 190 nations. ""It would not be easy for anybody to just say 'I want to renegotiate this'

column1: Nations who agreed in Paris range from top greenhouse gas emitters China and the United States
column2: small island nations fearful of rising sea levels and OPEC members who depend on income from oil.Renegotiation ""is really not a scenario that in a multilateral process you can see as something feasible
column3: she added.Espinosa said she would be ""respectful of everybody who has a role to play in any country"" but at the same time seek to build momentum for action. Many other backers of the accord have expressed dismay at Trump's call.

column1: The Paris Agreement will enter into force once 55 nations responsible for 55 percent of global emissions formally ratify the deal. So far
column2: 16 nations have ratified
column3: accounting for just 0.03 percent of emissions. Many nations
column4: including China and the United States which together represent 38 percent of emissions
column5: say they will join this year. Espinosa
column6: 57 and now Mexico's ambassador to Germany
column7: will succeed Christiana Figueres of Costa Rica

column1: Espinosa said she also will seek to link action to curb climate change to all aspects of development in coming years.She agreed with Figueres
